title: Download container images for OO on OpenShift
content:
To install an application, you will need to download the required installation images. You need to:

  • Generate an image download tool package
  • Run the download script inside the tool package to download the required installation images.

Generate the download bundle

The generate_download_bundle.sh script compares the images listed in the image-set.json file with the images that already exist in the specified image organization of the specified registry. It will only download the missing images.

  1. Log on to the first bastion node.
  2. Run the following command to change the directory: cd ${CDF_HOME}/tools/generate-download.
  3. Run the command together with the options required by your deployment. For example, run the following command: 
    ./generate_download_bundle.sh --chart <OO helm chart file> -o <org name> [-d <destination dir>]

    Where:
    <OO helm chart file> is the absolute path to the downloaded OO Helm chart package.
    <org name> is the organization in the image registry that contains the images for installation. Default is hpeswitom.
    <destination dir> is the directory where the output .zip file gets created. Default is the current directory.

The generate_download_bundle.sh script compares the images needed by the suite with the images that already exist in the cluster, and generates a .zip file, offline-download.zip. The offline-download.zip file enables you to download the required images from Docker Hub. For example: 

./generate_download_bundle.sh oo-xxx-xx/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-xxx.xx.tgz -o hpeswitom

The offline-download.zip file gets saved under the current working directory unless you specify a different directory using the "-d" option. You receive the following messages indicating that you have successfully generated the offline-download.zip file:

[INFO] 2022-07-31 17:58:46 : ** Generating the offline image download bundle ... [INFO] 2022-07-31 17:58:50 : Completed generation of offline-download.zip in /tmp

Download the required installation images

  1. Log on to the first bastion node. If the first bastion node can't access Docker Hub, transfer the  offline-download.zip file to a Linux server that can access Docker Hub.
  2. Extract the .zip package to a directory. If you can't access Docker Hub directly, set up the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. For example, run the following commands to set the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. Replace the placeholders with your actual server and port.  
    export http_proxy="<http://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
export https_proxy="<https://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
  3. Go to the directory where you extracted the offline-download.zip file.
  4. Run the following command:  
    ./downloadimages.sh [-r <image repository URL>] [-u <username>] [-d <image download directory>] [-c on|off]
    In <image repository URL>, specify the -r option if you want to download the images from a repository other than Docker Hub.

    Replace <username> with the Docker Hub username.

    If you don't specify the credentials here, specify them when you run the command, at the prompt.

    <image download directory>: The directory where the container images are downloaded. The default value is /var/opt/kubernetes/offline.

    Use the -c option to verify the digital signature of the images during the download. The default setting is off, which doesn't verify the signature.

To see the full list of options for the downloadimages.sh command, run the command: ./downloadimages.sh –h.
The command also has a -p option to enter your password. The -p  option doesn't support single quotes (don't include single quotes in the password).

By selecting the -p option, you are disabling or bypassing security features, thereby exposing the system to increased security risks. Transfer the images to the bastion node

If you downloaded the images to a server other than the first bastion node, transfer the images to a directory on the first bastion node. By default, the images are placed under the /var/opt/kubernetes/offline directory.

The uploadimages.sh script uploads the images later. The image upload requires up to 2 times of the image size space in the target image directory. If you choose the default /var/opt/kubernetes/offline directory, ensure that you have two times of the OMT and suite image size space under the /var/opt/kubernetes/offline directory of the bastion node.
